column4: wake on lan, or some types of bios let you set a time to turn the computer on, but either way that's fairly hardware-specific and WOL requires something else on the LAN to wake your comptuter up
is there some reason you can't just leave the computer on?
I wouldn't feel comfortable leaving it on for a span of days...it gets pretty warm and crashes
even with having to buy it?
computers are not supposed to crash if left on.  Either your hardware is broken or your case isn't cooled well, or the computer's in a hot environment with no AC
it's an ancient computer, from 2002...it crashes and it crashes a lot. I only use it to run cron jobs anyway
can you get a cheap low-power embedded computer (even a wireless gateway would suffice... buffalo wifi are cheap at $65-70 and have lots of flash and ram) and run the cronjobs from that?
since you got the computer, have you reapplied thermal compound and reseated the cpu cooler and gotten rid of dust
and have you run memtest86 overnight?
most likely...it's usually fine, it's just on a really warm day it gets too warm...and were in the middle of summer :P
is the cron stuff specific to that computer or could any computer do it without much trouble
even if the NIC/bios supports wake on lan, you'd need another computer on the LAN to wake it up...
I think any computer could do it...however I'm in the process of implimenting the link quin gave me which involves setting a timer
the only other option I can think of is some sort of telephone-controlled power switch, if you have a landline
but that would be more expensive than an embedded low-power system like a wireless gateway
I did at one point try to hack the router my ISP have given us...but with no luck
I meant the telephone power switch.  even LAN (web-based) power switches (turn on/off power sockets) would cost $100ish or more
but I can program it to switch on after a timer in the OS itself using ACPI: http://blog.gulfsoft.com/2010/05/scheduled-wakeup-in-ubuntu.html
if that works, that's really cool.  I've always regarded desktop power management stuff as unreliable, maybe it's reliable these days
